author: Qatar Tribune
title: 80% of Qatarâ€™s CEOs predict growth in their organisations - Read Qatar Tribune on the go for unrivalled news coverage
text:
Tribune News Network
Doha
KPMG in Qatarâ€™s 2023 CEO Outlook Report has delved into the ever-evolving economic and geopolitical landscape, revealing how Qatarâ€™s CEOs are strategically navigating uncertainty with unwavering optimism.
â€œWe find CEOs navigating economic uncertainties with optimism, prioritizing disruptive technologies such as generative AI, and championing ESG governance for improved stakeholder returns.
â€œDespite challenges ranging from cyber threats to regulatory hurdles, their commitment to integrity and long-term strategic planning remains firm - ready to make bold decisions for the greater good, even in complex times,â€ emphasizes Ahmed Abu-Sharkh, Country Senior Partner at KPMG in Qatar.
Qatarâ€™s CEOs proudly express an exceptional 80% confidence in the growth path of their organizations and industries for the next three years.
This not only exceeds the perspectives of their global counterparts but highlights a distinct strategic emphasis on organic growth, digitization, and resilient practices, even in the face of economic uncertainties.
Qatarâ€™s CEOs do however express more caution when it comes to national and global economic growth. â€œQatar CEOs shine with unwavering optimism for organizational growth, navigating nationwide challenges with a keen eye on emerging technology and cyber risks, exemplifying resilience and strategic foresight,â€ said Venkat Krishnaswamy, Partner, Head of Advisory, KPMG in Qatar.
Qatarâ€™s CEOs have begun to recognize ESGâ€™s long-term benefits in enhancing brand, customer relations, and talent attraction, despite potential challenges such as increased costs and stakeholder scrutiny.
â€œThe potential for growth and positive change through ESG is undeniable,â€ notes Omar Mahmood, Partner and Head of Financial Services at KPMG in Qatar, â€œQatarâ€™s CEOs have a golden opportunity to harness this momentum, strengthen stakeholder bonds, and elevate their ESG initiatives to help drive long-term sustainable growth.â€ Overall, ESG is seen as a transformative force, not just a trend, in corporate strategy.
The KPMGâ€™s CEO Outlook report reveals a nuanced perspective on the future of workforce in Qatar.
While 72% anticipate a full office return and 24% contemplate hybrid models, there seems to be a strong focus on inclusion, diversity, and equity (IDE), Barbara Henzen, Partner, and Head of Tax at KPMG in Qatar emphasizes, â€œIn todayâ€™s dynamic business landscape, forward-thinking CEOs recognize the undeniable power of inclusion, diversity, and equity as catalysts for sustainable growth. Embracing diverse leadership is not just progressiveâ€”itâ€™s essential for future success.â€
With a clear understanding of AIâ€™s transformative potential, 44% of Qatarâ€™s CEOs prioritize its investment, focusing on profitability, efficiency, innovation, and cybersecurity.
Despite challenges in employee adoption, ethics, technical skills, and regulatory gaps, CEOs remain resilient, viewing regulation as both a hurdle and a necessary element for responsible AI practices.
Nizar Hneini, Partner and Head of Digital & Innovation at KPMG in Qatar, highlights, â€œGenerative AI is transforming business - promising innovation and efficiency. CEOs, while addressing challenges, are committed to responsibly leveraging AIâ€™s potential, ensuring ethical use and robust governance, paving the way for prosperous growth and a tech-enabled future.â€
This yearâ€™s report presents significant insights and official statements contributed by esteemed leaders in the business landscape, including Sheikh Ali Bin Jabor Al Thani, Chief Executive Officer of Ooredoo Qatar; Salman Gulzar, Country Head of Mashreq Bank; Abdul Hakeem Mostafawi, Chief Executive Officer of HSBC Qatar; Salem Al-Mannai, Chief Executive Officer of QIC Group; Ibrahim Bn Khalid Al Sulaiti, President of YEC; and Sheikh Hamad Abdulla Jassim Al-Thani, Chief Executive Officer of Vodafone Qatar.
In summary, Qatarâ€™s CEOs, as revealed in the KPMG Qatar 2023 CEO Outlook Report, transcend challenges with unwavering optimism.
 Copy 29/12/2023 70

author: Corrie Pelc
title: Cancer vaccine with immunotherapy shrinks liver tumors, trial shows
text:
- Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common form of liver cancer, accounting for more than 80% of cases.
- Immunotherapy is one of the newest treatment options for HCC, but not everyone responds to it.
- Researchers from Johns Hopkins Kimmel Cancer Center found combining immunotherapy with a personalized anti-tumor vaccine increased tumor shrinkage compared to immunotherapy alone.
Liver cancer is the
sixth most common cancer in the world. Researchers estimate03022-7/fulltext) 905,700 people were diagnosed with liver cancer in 2020 and that number is expected to hit 1.4 million by 2040. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) liver cancer, accounting for more than 80% of all cases
One of the newest treatment options for HCC is
immunotherapy past studies00178-2/fulltext) show only 15â€“20% of HCC diagnoses respond to immunotherapy and about 30% may be resistant.
Now, the results of a preliminary clinical trial show that people with HCC treated with immunotherapy and a
personalized anti-tumor vaccine
The results of the trial were published April 7 in
Nature Medicine
This preliminary clinical trial was for
GNOS-PV02 â€” a personalized DNA vaccine created by Geneos Therapeutics.
â€œEssentially GNOS-PV02 aims to (educate) the immune system to recognize antigens that are present in the cancer so that the immune system can better recognize and attack cancer cells,â€ explained lead study author
Mark Yarchoan, MD, associate professor of oncology at the Johns Hopkins Kimmel Cancer Center.
â€œThe vaccine is personalized for each individual patientâ€™s cancer. Just the way that every person has a unique fingerprint, every cancer has its own set of unique antigens that are derived from unique DNA mutations within the cancer,â€ Yarchoan told Medical News Today.
â€œTo make a personalized vaccine, first a biopsy is obtained of the cancer, and the cancer DNA is sequenced to identify the potential unique antigens within the cancer. Then a personalized vaccine is manufactured that encodes the unique antigens identified in the analysis of the tumor biopsy.â€
â€” Mark Yarchoan, MD, lead study author
GNOS-PV02 was used in conjunction with the immunotherapy drug
pembrolizumab, known under the brand name Keytruda.
The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) granted
approval
â€œDespite recent advances in the treatment of HCC, only a minority of patients respond to contemporary systemic treatments and the prognosis for patients with advanced disease is inferior to most other tumor types,â€ Yarchoan said.
Yarchoan noted that until recently, most cancer vaccines failed in the clinic, citing a number of potential reasons as to why.
â€œOne reason is that past cancer vaccines usually targeted antigens that werenâ€™t specific enough to the cancer,â€ he said. â€œMost cancer antigens are unique to an individual cancer, and the technology to personalize cancer vaccines has only been possible very recently.â€
â€œBut the other reason why cancer vaccines generally failed in the clinic is that they were used against advanced cancers, without any other immunotherapy,â€ Yarchoan continued.
â€œWeâ€™ve learned that vaccines can cause immune cells to become exhausted before they can eliminate cancer cells. For this reason, contemporary cancer vaccines are often combined with other immune-activating therapies like pembrolizumab. This prevents the vaccine-induced T cells from becoming exhausted,â€ he explained.
Researchers recruited 36 participants for this clinical trial. All participants received the combination of GNOS-PV02 vaccine and pembrolizumab.
At the end of the study, researchers found that almost one-third of participants experienced tumor shrinkage, which is about twice as many people seen in studies of immunotherapy alone for HCC.
Additionally, about 8% of the study participants had no evidence of a tumor after receiving the combination treatment.
â€œThe response rate on this study is high enough that I think itâ€™s unlikely that the pembrolizumab alone did this â€” it supports the idea that the vaccine contributed to the efficacy observed,â€ Yarchoan said.
â€œI think itâ€™s also notable that the response rate was higher than pembrolizumab alone without a major increase in toxicity.â€
â€œI think the results are highly encouraging, but larger randomized studies are needed to confirm the efficacy of personalized cancer vaccines and to define the optimal treatment sequence for their use. Larger clinical studies are being planned by (Geneos Therapeutics) and Iâ€™m hopeful that such studies will confirm that this vaccine is an active agent.â€
â€” Mark Yarchoan, MD, lead study author
After reviewing the results of this study,
Anton Bilchik, MD, PhD, surgical oncologist, chief of medicine and Director of the Gastrointestinal and Hepatobiliary Program at Providence Saint Johnâ€™s Cancer Institute in Santa Monica, CA, told MNT he was â€œabsolutely astonishedâ€ at the results in this early vaccine trial.
â€œHCC is one of the most common cancers in the world and itâ€™s typically been very resistant to treatment,â€ Bilchik explained. â€œRecently, immunotherapy has been introduced as a possible treatment for patients with advanced HCC, but the response rates for immunotherapy have not been great.â€
â€œWhat this study does is take patientsâ€™ own tumor and create a personalized vaccine, which doubles the response of the immunotherapy that is currently used for HCC,â€ he continued. â€œNot only are the results astonishing, but these are patients that have failed first-line treatment and are not amenable to resection or transplantation.â€
MNT also spoke with
Martin Gutierrez, MD, director of Phase I research at the John Theurer Cancer Center at Hackensack University Medical Center in New Jersey, about this study.
â€œ(This is) very encouraging news,â€ Gutierrez commented. â€œ(The next research step should be a) larger Phase II trial in first-line therapy.â€
When asked if we will see more personalized cancer vaccines in the future, Bilchik said absolutely.
â€œThis is the future. And what makes this approach unique is that not only are they using the patientâ€™s own tumor biopsy cells to identify these mutations, but they take it a step further by using these computational algorithms to predict which genes can be recognized by the patientâ€™s own immune system. So this is getting into the field of really advanced technology and then ultimately artificial intelligence.â€
â€” Anton Bilchik, MD, PhD, surgical oncologist

author: Anthony Robledo
title: Viral photo of forlorn Spiral Hot Dogs owner leads to booming business
text: Customer's photo of forlorn owner in empty restaurant leads business to boom at OK diner Nick Chappell had never been to Spirals Hot Dogs & More before he took a photo of Scott Hosek in his empty restaurant. But after business boomed, Chappell's part of the Spirals family, Hosek says. [Anthony Robledo](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7612431001/anthony-robledo/) An Oklahoma hot dog joint owner visibly wanted customers one day and he soon got more than he bargained for. During a slow shift on Dec. 20, a customer took a photo of Scott Hosek standing by his restaurant entrance waiting for diners and shared it on social media. Hosek would soon have no time to stand around as " [Spirals: Hot Dogs & More](https://spiralshotdogs.com/)," in Norman, Oklahoma, saw booming business once the post went viral. "We immediately started doing double digits in sales," Hosek told USA TODAY on Thursday. "It happened really fast to me." The day the photo was taken, Hosek found himself staring out the window upset his family business of four years wasn't booming as well as others ahead of Christmas. Hosek said he had no idea why Spirals saw a sudden wave of new customers after Dec. 20 until the person responsible for posting the photo, Nick Chappell, later apologized and offered to take the post down. Hosek wouldn't hear of it. "You just wouldn't expect it. Social media is amazing. It's amazing that people get involved with it," he said. "But more importantly, it's the stuff that you just don't think would work. That's what works." 'I will always love you': [See Dolly Parton grant Utah man's dying wish to meet her](/story/life/humankind/2023/12/26/dolly-parton-meets-longtime-fan/72033945007/) Customer knew he had to capture 'wholesome moment' Chappell visited the Norman area for his job as an Oklahoma Army National Guard. As part of their weekly hot dog Wednesday routine, Chappell and a his co-worker found Spirals on Google Maps and took a chance. Noticing Hosek gazing, Chappell decided to capture the "wholesome moment" on Snapchat captioning "He has been standing here waiting on customers to come in." "A good buddy of mine named Chad said, 'Hey, man, you can either post this on Facebook or I'm going to post this on Facebook. Some way or another we're going to get this guy some customers,'" Chappell said. In a Facebook post, Chappell gave an excellent recommendation of the restaurant, complimenting their food and "off the charts" service. He shared a photo of his dish, the menu and of Hosek waiting for diners. Chappell was blown away by the success of the post, which has since had over 2,000 shares, and even more surprised to see over 70 guests at the diner during his next visit. "I'm not a huge social media guy I typically don't share," Chappell said. "I don't even know really the words to describe it as but it made me even that much happier that I did make a post." Owner adds new 'Thunderbird' item in customer's honor Hosek is showing his gratitude by adding a new item in Chappell's honor. Having named hot dogs and bowls after family members, he was more than happy to do so. The "Thunderbird" is a hot link with bacon, cream cheese and jalapeÃ±os, Hosek said. The meal gets its name from the Thunderbird Unit Patch for the 45th Infantry, which Chappell is a part of. The two reconnected at the restaurant on Thursday, where they both got emotional talking about the post's impact. Chappell received a certificate of appreciation during the unveiling of the "Thunderbird" and was told he is now forever part of the Spirals family. "To know that it was a humble guy that just saw our need and did what he could. He doesnâ€™t have a real following on social media, he hardly ever shares anything and to know that one post had so much power. It was super cool," Hosek added.

author: Tania Divine
title: This Is The Ugly Truth About Mesothelioma Asbestos Lawyers
text:
mesothelioma lawsuit Lawyers
It is essential to select the right law firm to handle your asbestos trust fund or mesothelioma claim. A national firm has a lot of experience litigating asbestos trust fund and mesothelioma attorney lawsuits all over the world.
Top firms offer mesothelioma attorneys, Yogicentral.science , who combine legal knowledge with compassion and love for their clients. Families and patients are made to feel as comfortable as they can throughout the lawsuit process.
They work on a per-contingency basis.
If an asbestos victim is diagnosed with mesothelioma, or another asbestos-related illness, they and their family have to deal with a variety of issues. A mesothelioma lawyer can ease much of the burden off of victims and their families by helping them comprehend their legal options and navigating the complicated legal process.
The best mesothelioma attorneys are skilled and dedicated to helping their clients and families win compensation. Their expertise includes filing an asbestos trust fund claim, analyzing the clientâ€™s exposure as well as taking depositions and argument in court.
Mesothelioma lawsuits are a bit more complicated and require a lot of research as well as resources to win. Mesothelioma lawyers can also connect their clients with world-class doctors and medical professionals to treat their asbestos illnesses.
Asbestos victims and their families could be entitled to compensation from negligent asbestos companies. Compensation can help pay for medical expenses as well as pay off debts and provide financial security for loved family members.
Attorneys are paid on a contingency basis, which means they donâ€™t charge upfront for their services. Instead, they are paid a portion of the amount that their client receives from the settlement or verdict. This arrangement helps ensure that the victim receives the entire amount they are entitled to.
Lawyers who specialize in mesothelioma are able to access a wealth of industry resources including proprietary asbestos databases and records of workplaces and other important information. They can investigate possible sources of asbestos exposure in patients and determine if the disease could have been prevented.
The asbestos industry was aware for a long time about asbestosâ€™ dangers but did not take the time to warn workers or consumers. Mesothelioma poses a serious risk to workers in manufacturing, construction power plants, shipyards and other industrial jobs. This includes factory workers, miners employees, asbestos insulation installers and manufacturers, railroad and automobile employees, plumbers, and construction crews.
Asbestos-related victims may sue these companies for negligence or failing to warn. This will result in a substantial amount of compensation. The money could be used to pay medical expenses, debts, loss of income, funeral costs, and funeral expenses. Additionally, it can enhance the quality of a victimâ€™s life and offer hope for the future.
They provide a free case Evaluation
When a family or individual receives a diagnosis of mesothelioma, they might be unsure about their case and the financial impact it could have. Attorneys who specialize in mesothelioma can help patients understand the legal options available to them and make it as easy as it can be.
Mesothelioma lawyers can assist patients and their loved ones determine how they were exposed to asbestos and the effects the exposure had on their lives. They can also help identify possible sources of compensation. Asbestos contaminated victims may be entitled to compensation damages that cover their past and ongoing medical expenses, loss of income emotional distress, and much more.
Attorneys who specialize in mesothelioma have the expertise to review and gather important evidence, including medical records and work histories, test results, asbestos-exposure locations, and a myriad of other factors. They also have the resources and connections to employ industrial hygienists and medical experts to aid in the development of their cases. Asbestos lawyers can also file lawsuits and claims on behalf of their clients, negotiate mesothelioma settlements, and even take cases to trial if needed.
In addition to filing personal injury or wrongful death lawsuits, mesothelioma lawyers can also file asbestos trust fund claims. Asbestos bankruptcy trusts were set by companies who were responsible for exposure of workers to asbestos, and submitting a claim against one of these trusts is a fantastic way to recover financial compensation.
They will make sure that you file your claim within the time frame of limitations. They will also handle all litigation so you can focus on improving your health.
Attorneys who specialize in mesothelioma provide an evaluation of mesothelioma for free to help patients and their families locate the best mesothelioma lawsuit attorneys for their situation. These attorneys are committed to ensuring that mesothelioma patients and their families get the highest compensation. They will work on a contingency basis, meaning they only take fees when they win their clientâ€™s case. This allows the victims and their loved ones to focus their attention on their health and recovery while knowing that their mesothelioma attorneys are doing all they can to get the compensation they deserve.
They are a part of the practice throughout the country.
Mesothelioma is a form of asbestos cancer, affects the protective lining around vital organs like the lung. Asbestos attorneys have experience litigating against asbestos-related companies that cause this deadly illness. These law firms are dedicated to getting victims and their families the compensation they deserve.
Asbestos law firms offer free case evaluations and work on a contingent basis, meaning they get paid only if their clients receive compensation. This method is geared towards the best interests of victims and assists them in receiving the highest settlement for mesothelioma possible.
Companies that specialize in mesothelioma are able to access extensive resources, including asbestos-specific databases. These databases aid in determining the patientsâ€™ exposure source. They also are aware of the specific industries and occupations with a high risk that could have exposed people to this dangerous substance. This allows them to build a strong claim against the responsible parties and secure compensation for their clients.
In addition to filing mesothelioma lawsuits and claims, these attorneys assist their clients in obtaining VA benefits and recouping out-of-pocket expenses. They are able to calculate the total damages of a victim and negotiate to maximize compensation.
Many asbestos companies that are responsible for mesothelioma, asbestosis and other asbestos-related diseases have gone bankrupt. They have set up trust funds to compensate the victims. Mesothelioma lawyers can assist clients in submitting a bankruptcy claim to these trusts.
The goal of asbestos law firms is to make the legal process as simple as possible for their clients. They keep their clients informed throughout the process and are prepared for trial in order to protect their clientsâ€™ rights.
In a mesothelioma case, lawyers create and present the evidence that asbestos exposure caused each clientâ€™s illness. To show the responsibility of the asbestos companies, lawyers will provide medical records, research and other data. They will argue that asbestos companies were aware of the dangers associated with their products, but they concealed this information and put their customers at risk for serious illness.
They travel to meet their Clients
A mesothelioma lawyer with experience can travel to meet with clients to discuss asbestos exposure, develop a case, and file the lawsuit in the most appropriate location. Some states have different statutes of limitations which determine when a lawsuit may be filed, and some have courts that are more suitable for these cases. Attorneys should also be aware of local resources for expert witnesses, such as industrial hygienists or medical professionals.
Mesothelioma attorneys must collect evidence to prove their clientâ€™s asbestos exposure as well as the severity of the symptoms. This may include medical documents, laboratory test results and work history, compensation claims, and other financial and employment-related documents. The mesothelioma attorneys can also help clients file VA disability claims.
In the United States, asbestos was used in many types of products. It was employed in many industries due to its cost, durability, and fire resistance. Unfortunately asbestos companies were aware of the dangers of exposure, but kept this information from the public. Asbestos victims deserve compensation for the harm done by these companies.
Many asbestos-related companies were faced with a lot of lawsuits from victims and had to declare bankruptcy. As a result, they created bankruptcy trusts which victims can claim from for compensation. A mesothelioma lawyer can assist clients file claims from these trusts by explaining the places they were exposed to asbestos and the manufacturers responsible for their exposure.
A mesothelioma suit can also seek compensation for losses, including lost wages, medical expenses and loss of a family member. Additionally mesothelioma lawsuits may also be a wrongful-death claim for a family member who has died from the illness.
The best mesothelioma attorneys work on a contingency basis and are able to prioritize their clientsâ€™ needs. They provide free case evaluations because they are aware of the financial challenges associated with the diagnosis of mesothelioma. These benefits help you hire the best legal representation for patients and their families.
